layer.name: Causality
layer.definition: Actions have consequences; you reap what you sow.

questions.text: Small compromises in integrity compound into larger character issues ...
questions.principle: Small causes compound into large effects

answers.4: usually — small things tend to grow over time
answers.5: reliably — small compromises always set trajectories
answers.3: sometimes — some compromises compound, others don't
answers.1: not necessarily — small things stay small

questions.text: Most 'sudden' moral failures are actually the result of many small prior choices ...

answers.4: usually — big falls have long approaches
answers.5: almost always — the trail of small choices is always there if you look
answers.2: possibly — but it's hard to trace
answers.3: sometimes — some failures have visible roots, others don't
answers.1: not really — some people just snap

questions.text: Honesty and deception have natural consequences ...
questions.principle: Truth and lies produce predictable outcomes

answers.4: generally — trust and suspicion follow predictably
answers.5: directly — you reap what you sow in relationships
answers.2: weakly — maybe eventually, but not consistently
answers.3: somewhat — there are patterns, but with many exceptions
answers.1: not reliably — honest people get burned, liars prosper

questions.text: When I ignore my conscience repeatedly, it becomes harder to hear ...
questions.principle: Conscience sensitivity responds to how you treat it

answers.4: usually — there's a clear connection between ignoring and dimming
answers.5: absolutely — this is cause and effect, not random
answers.2: possibly — but conscience seems to come and go randomly
answers.3: sometimes — it's quieter in some areas, not others

questions.text: The quality of my relationships connects to how I've treated people ...

answers.4: generally — how I treat people usually comes back
answers.5: directly — the harvest matches the seed
answers.3: partially — some relationships reflect my treatment, others don't
answers.1: not really — relationships seem to succeed or fail randomly
